original_data.question: A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of genital lesions. She has no history of serious illness. She is sexually active with 2 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows multiple hyperkeratotic exophytic papules over the vulva. The lesions turn white on application of 3% acetic acid. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?

model_response:
This patient has condylomata acuminata, a sexually transmitted disease. The causative organism is human papillomavirus (HPV), which may be transmitted by skin-to-skin contact with infected genital skin or mucosa. The incubation period is 3-4 months. The lesions may be seen with the naked eye, but a magnified examination with a colposcope is often necessary. The lesions are hyperkeratotic papules that may coalesce to form large cauliflower-like growths. The lesions turn white with the application of 3% acetic acid, which "burns off" the excess keratin. The application of 5% acetic acid to cervical epithelium infected with HPV causes the epithelium to "melt" (acetowhite). HPV types 6 and 11 are usually associated with external genital warts. HPV types 16 and 18 are usually associated with cervical dysplasia and cervical cancer. The diagnosis of HPV infection is made by DNA hybridization with typespecific probes. Condoms can prevent the spread of HPV, but they are not 100% effective because they may fail (break or slip off) or may not cover the external genital warts. Anti-HIV prophylaxis does not prevent HPV infection. Spermicidal foam may prevent infection by killing sperm, but it will not prevent HPV infection. Vaccination with the recombinant HPV vaccine prevents infection with HPV types 6, 11, 16, and 18.

###Answer: OPTION D IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Having a black or dark core or plug.
Record and study of past events.
Record and study of past events.
A state of ill health, bodily malfunction, or discomfort.
A response indicating that an individual is or was sexually active.
A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both.
A sheath that is worn over the penis during sexual behavior in order to prevent pregnancy or spread of sexually transmitted disease.
Actions performed to measure temperature, pulse, respirations, and blood pressure
External and internal inspection of the FEMALE GENITALIA. (from Dictionary of Obstetrics and Gynecology)

A circumscribed, solid elevation of skin with no visible fluid, varying in size from a pinhead to less than 10mm in diameter at the widest point that is composed of localized hyperkeratosis (the latter may be demonstrated histopathologically). [PMID:3632007]
The external genitalia of the female. It includes the CLITORIS, the labia, the vestibule, and its glands.
A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part.

A group distinguished by classification according to physical features. This group, also called Europoid, centers around the Mediterranean Sea but includes other parts of Europe. (from Winick: Dictionary of Anthropology, 1972; American Heritage Dictionary, 2d College ed)
Product of the oxidation of ethanol and of the destructive distillation of wood. It is used locally, occasionally internally, as a counterirritant and also as a reagent. (Stedman, 26th ed)

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
A state of being, such as a state of health.
